replies.author: @xxplayer2kxx
replies.text:
Abolishing money and private property is reactionary and represents landlords and land holding peasants somehow, despite the fact that they literally collectivised agriculture and nationalised all industry...

BTW, the colonial 'development' of urban centres was parasitic on the peasantry, being a cause of underdevelopment of dependency on imperialist foreign powers. The mobilisation of the people to the country side was a necessary measure for post-war construction.

And Vietnam is a real socialist country because it restored the rule of money and private property in the country, abolished the dictatorship of the proletariat, and carried out acts of expansionism in Indochina region in collusion with forces of social-imperialism: Mai Phuc brigades of nationalists and fascists, gangs and warlords, and even CIA.

History will vindicate the Khmer Krahom.

replies.author: @Huy-G-Le
replies.text: ‚Äã@ is this what khmer rouge supporter believe in? Hah, now that is interest, this is literally rural conservativeness, but at least it's a legit ideological path.

replies.author: @Huy-G-Le
replies.text:
@ I wonder if this is out of a misunderstanding of what private property mean, because the farms lands that were removed from the urban and rural feudal lords, and given ownerships to the people who already works on them. 

*Those are not private property, those are personal property.*

Why? It's call personal property because the worker/farmer/peasant working on that lands use that lands to produces their owns products. 

While private property is similar but instead of the person/family/clan/whatever organization owns that lands, doesn't works on that lands to produces product, but use the labor of other people to produces products, and then give them back only a portions of what they produces, while the people doesn't produces, but the owns the lands, get the majority of the products other people produces, and essential have the right to decides how much to give to the worker because the worker don't owns the lands, but the people who owns the lands, landlord do.

Your understanding of the dictatorship of the proletariat is also off by a ridiculous margin. What that just mean, is the worker government is in charges AND the powers of the working people are supreme, above the interest of business and landlord and clergy. 

The Soviet simply change the dictatorship of the proletariat into dictatorship of the party, which naturally would transfer the ownerships of the mean of production from worker collective to the state.

But comparing other version elsewhere, Bulgaria for example. Rural population allow to owns reasonable portions of lands, and produce products on that lands which they works and produces and decided what to do with the product, although since market mechanism were limited, it's essentially just mean storing and the farming eating it or giving it to other.

Also during Lenin time, nationalized industries, meaning the infrastructure, fuels and manufacturing (Agricultural were mostly collective worker coop) because the Soviet need those thing up and running fast and without nationalization, there were no other ways to get it's going fast enough, although the ideal scenario would had nationalized industries then socialized them. 

For example, Rojava PYD oils industry are cooperative owns. 

I simply found your reasoning... ridiculous, but can be consider as socialistic measure, but instead of its being the result of analysis using the marxian method or keynesian method, its use came out from anger and hatred from rural population who isolated themselves from the broader working people struggle.

replies.author: @xxplayer2kxx
replies.text:
@Huy-G-Le Firstly, they had to develop socialist agriculture and create grain surpluses before they could industrialise, Industrialisation being the material base for social revolution, but the economy was made to be poor and dependent from French colonialism and U.S. bombings. They had to lay a solid foundation if their were to be any Kampuchean revolution. 

Secondly, personal property is not a definite category but an abstraction which has nothing to do with political economy, given the fact that every property has personal utility regardless of its class character belonging to a definite stage in the development of the productive forces. The property relations you are referring to are feudal and semi-feudal relations which must be abolished with the modernisation and collectivisation of agriculture for socialist construction. Your support of small agriculture and forms of peasant democracy are nothing but concessions to petty bourgeois democracy.

In Kampuchea there was insecurity of food after the war and vast masses of the population had to be mobilised into great agricultural armies so that there would not be famine, and so that Khmer could trade for modern equipment and heavy machinery as the basis for industrialisation. Socialist industrialisation cannot occur in a country unless it has replaced backwards agriculture with large scale agriculture. it is necessarily the priority of construction, to consolidate the proletariat, so that there may be socialist revolution.

Your understanding is muddled, firstly, by not understanding the relation of proletarian dictatorship to the peasantry, and secondly, the nature of proletarian dictatorship itself. Proletarian dictatorship is the rule of the proletarian class over the bourgeoisie, unrestricted by law.
In a country where the proletariat constitute a minority it is vital to meet the needs of the peasantry with that of the proletariat ad to utilise the revolutionary potential of the peasantry.
This is not the dictatorship of all working people, but the dictatorship of the proletariat in particular, which, though not necessarily antagonistic to the interests of working people, is the historical mission of that class which is socialist by nature, that is not true of just any class.

The party had the support of the proletariat, but was couped by technical intelligentsia, manifested in Khrushchev's 20th congress.
Worker collective is not whole people's ownership, it is therefore only one form of socialist property, not the complete form.
Socialism is a mode of production, not a technical apparatus of politically organising workspaces, that is called utopian democratic socialism, advanced by Owen and the English communists of the 19th century.
Scientific communism says: industry does not need to be compartmentalised or democratised, both serving the continued existence of the state (see Engels on social-democracy, Lenin on syndicalism), but must be centralised into a single economic entity according to a central plan, i.e.. society taking possession over all branches: agriculture plus agriculture plus electricity, etc.

I don't care if you find Marxism ridiculous, enjoy being fundamentally wrong I guess.

Together with Liebknecht she formed the Communist Party of Germany (KPD) after SPD supported the war. In fact the reason she was murdered was because she was THIS terrifying to the German bourgeoisie. As Lenin put it: she was an "eagle" of working class with intellectual prowess and true revolutionary spirit. Easy A tier

replies.author: @Frida_22-l
replies.text: In addition to Western, Russian and Chinese communists, you should also be interested in African and Latin American communists and socialists and socialists in general, whether they are social democrats or non-Marxists or agrarians. Socialist societies are interesting, for example Laos, DDR, China's Mao era peoples communes and other collective social experiments such as kibbutzim or the only successful free market society, the Faroe Islands. Communism is a utopia, a bit like nirvana or heaven that you can never get to.  I myself live in Finland and in my country communists and socialists are people who not only hate themselves but also humanity and live in a green-left and liberal bubble and they have gays in mind and they have abandoned workers as a reactionary relic and believe that if Finland stops its own industry and moves factories to China so that we don't feel guilty about producing emissions, stopping breathing as a way to combat climate change, giving foreign aid by borrowing and raising taxes, dismantles the welfare state and gives away decision-making power and sovereignty, then we will become the favorites of the EU Commission and others will start to do the same. In Finland some people jokingly say that Finland should exchange social democrats with Sweden because Finnish social democrats are just as destructive as right-wingers because Finland has not had economic growth for 17 years and the state will go bankrupt at some point.  The left took my country into NATO and now the left complains that defense spending is too high. Before NATO membership, there was no talk of the possibility of war. Now, as a NATO member, we hear about the possibility of conflict with Russia.

replies.author: @Tuomasboss
replies.text:
‚Äã@jan5456 I am Finnish myself too, and I find it ironic that the ‚Äúleft‚Äù in Finland, who often present themselves as the most anti-American, are, in fact, the most Americanized people in the country.

Take, for example, the Sami rights movement that has gained traction among Finnish leftists over the past few decades. Its rhetoric and framing are almost a direct copy of the American Landback movement. The Finnish left is eager to moralize about how the Sami were historically oppressed and dispossessed by other Nordic peoples, portraying it as an eternal crime that must forever be at the center of political debate. Of course, injustices against the Sami did occur, I am not denying that. But the way the Finnish left emphasizes this history is a mirror image of how the American left moralizes about the colonization of the Americas.

The same pattern appears in the culture wars, for example LGBT activism. They are not rooted in Finnish reality, but are instead imported wholesale from the American left and grafted onto Finnish politics. Most of the Finnish left‚Äôs defining causes are not truly Finnish at all, they are borrowed from abroad, especially America.

This is one of the main reasons why the Finnish left has become so alienated from the working class. By replacing genuine class-based politics with imported American cultural battles, the leftists have left ordinary workers behind and pushed many of them toward right-wing populist parties.

Their supposed anti-Americanism is only superficial. It is not rooted in independence from American influence, but rather in the same grievances voiced by American leftists themselves. That is why, for example, many Finnish leftists express hostility toward the U.S. now in response to Donald Trump‚Äôs election. Their opposition to America mirrors American leftist politics. It is derivative, not authentic.

The truly anti-American stance would be to reject these imported cultural issues altogether and insist on a distinctly Finnish political identity. That would mean rejecting NATO alignment, rejecting American media narratives, rejecting copycat Landback-movements and others, and focusing instead on Finnish realities. The contemporary left will label this position ‚Äúfar-right,‚Äù but in truth it is exactly what a genuine left movement must do if it hopes to reconnect with the working class.

author: @dashi3l
text:
putting stalin and mao in s-tier while calling trotsky a fascist is all you need to know about how unserious this video is and the amount of research you have done. you‚Äôre not doing marxism‚Äîyou‚Äôre doing cosplay authoritarianism.

trotsky co-led the russian revolution, founded the red army, and was murdered by stalin's regime for opposing the bureaucratic degeneration of the ussr. calling him a fascist is purely a stalinist line‚Äîthe same one that justified gulags, purges, and mass repression.

and no, industrialising through mass famine, utilising forced labor, and siding with the ruling class doesn‚Äôt make stalin or mao ‚Äúchads.‚Äù It makes them cautionary tales in the history of socialism.

replies.author: @ulyanov17
replies.text:
trotsky was a menshevik who fckd over the ussr multiple times - starting with brest-litovsk negotiations.
thinking you can avhieve commuism without authority od the dictatorship od the proletariat is all you need to know about how unserious this comment is

replies.author: @dashi3l
replies.text: @ulyanov17 i get where you're coming from with the need for centralised authority, but trotsky‚Äôs issue with stalin wasn‚Äôt about rejecting authority or the dictatorship of the proletariat‚Äîit was about the form of authority that led to bureaucratic decay. trotsky wasn't trying to sabotage the ussr‚Äîhe was trying to preserve the revolution's potential. his critique of things like brest-litovsk wasn‚Äôt about rejecting authority, it was about ensuring the long-term survival of the revolution. the gulags, purges, and repression under stalin went against everything trotsky and lenin envisioned for socialism. stalin created a state that was authoritarian and disconnected from the internationalist and democratic goals of october.

replies.author: @SebastianForal
replies.text: This video isn't meant to be serious, but trotsky was an absolute disaster, lenin himself said so. I've already told hundreds of people about why stalin and mao were better than trotsky in a million different ways but honestly I don't have the strength to continue.
